college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Economic agents often do not behave as the rational Homo Economicus. In behavioral economics the standard economic models and theories are adapted to incorporate the economically most relevant findings from psychology. Thereby, behavioral economic research strives to develop models with a higher predictive power than standard economic models. The challenge for behavioral economics is to maintain the balance between predictive power and complexity of the models.

This course will give an up-to-date overview of the most relevant behavioral economic models. Students will learn the differences between the various models. This will enable them to recognize which type of model is most appropriate in specific contexts.

  Leerdoelen
  • Students learn the most common alternatives to standard economic decision models. Topics covered are decision making under uncertainty, decision making over time, and social preferences.
  • Students learn to derive behavioural predictions from the decision models discussed.
  • Students learn to recognize whether or not observed behaviour satisfies a particular model.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Because of COVID-19, the course will be offered online. Exact details will become clear a few weeks before the start of the course.  ​

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Over the past several decades, the dominant paradigm in financial research has been the rational expectations hypothesis based on the notion that investors and managers are generally rational. The rational expectations hypothesis leads to the efficient market hypothesis, which stipulates that asset prices incorporate all available information.
However, anecdotal evidence as well as theoretical and empirical research show that the rational expectations paradigm is insufficient to describe various characteristics of financial markets. Behavioral finance is another approach to studying financial markets. It argues that certain financial outcomes can be better explained and understood using models in which some agents are not fully rational.

This course examines how the insights of behavioral finance complement the traditional paradigm and sheds light on asset price determination, corporate finance decisions, and various Wall Street institutional practices. The course focuses on the application of behavioral finance to two main topics: corporate finance and investments.

Corporate finance aims to understand the financial decisions of companies and extensively deals with agency problems arising from the separation of ownership and control between shareholders and managers. In the course, we will study both the case in which rational managers interact with less than fully rational investors (e.g., in the context of market timing theories) as well as situations where managerial behaviour is less than fully rational (e.g., due to managerial overconfidence), and explore the implications for corporate financial decisions such as investments, M&A activity or capital structure.

Another fruitful application of the concepts of behavioral finance is to financial bubbles, defined as prolonged periods of rising prices to levels inconsistent with fundamental economic assessments. The rising prices are subsequently followed by sharp declines, sometimes even price crashes. During the course, we will analyse the conditions that create a bubble in experimental settings as well as review recent financial bubbles such as the Dot-com bubble or the U.S. housing bubble.

In the investments section of the course, we will study behavioral biases in individual investors' portfolio choices leading to insufficient or naive diversification, excessive trading, etc. Next to direct (stock) investments we will also look at issues related to the investment in mutual funds (e.g., return-chasing behaviour, mutual fund benchmark distortions), accounting for the fact that, nowadays, individuals invest the vast majority of their savings through financial institutions. The course may touch upon various other topics including the implications of behavioral biases among institutional asset managers, and the question of whether individual financial decisions can be improved through education.
  Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into the recent and rapidly expanding literature on behavioural finance.
  • Students have understanding of how behavioural finance differs from traditional financial theory.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into the effects of psychological biases on financial decision making.
  • Students have knowledge of alternative methods to study financial decision making.
  • Students are able to distinguish behavioural approaches to finance from traditional ones.
  • Students are able to recognize behavioural biases in decision making, for both their own decisions and others.
Extra Non-programmable calculator allowed.​

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description
 
This course covers the more challenging and complex issues that analysts, investors, and financial advisors encounter when they evaluate company performance and firm equity value. It adopts a very pragmatic approach towards valuation. Students will be taught how valuation works in practices while drawing from theory. We have selected three analytical challenges that will be discussed in more detail:
»    Advanced Financial Analysis & Valuation Tools: Introducing Equity versus Enterprise value methods; identifying Enterprise Value Multiples; accounting issues in enterprise value; forecasting earnings for enterprise value; sum-of-the –parts valuation; Economic Value Added (EVA), real options in enterprise value; dealing with contingent claims character of equity and debt and valuation of private firms and start-ups.
»    Understanding Risk in Analysis and Valuation: Sources of risk; motives for risk management; Miller & Modigliani and risk management; hedging with financial instruments; accounting for derivative instruments; reflecting risk management in financial statements; dealing with risk management in equity valuation and particularly understanding how firms manage risk in their supply chain. Cost of Capital complications, Capital Structure impact of risk management and how that affects equity value.
»    Applied Analysis & Valuation for Banks: Banking Business Models; regulatory background; financial statements for banks; controversial issues in reporting for banks; analyzing bank performance; drivers of value creations; decomposing return on equity for banks; applying valuation methodologies such as Dividend Discount Models, Equity Multiples for banks.
  Leerdoelen Learning Objectives

At the end of this course students should be able to:
»    Understand the concept of enterprise value and its different claims;
»     Apply analysis and valuation techniques to conglomerates, private firms, start-ups and spin-offs;
»    Get familiar with valuation tools such as Bloomberg, Thomson One, DataStream and use them to build a valuation model
»     Understand, derive and interpret the key metrics to evaluate contingent and fixed claims;
»    Apply valuation techniques to contingent and fixed claims;
»    Understand complex accounting measurements such as share options, fair value accounting, leases and how they affect valuation
»     Understand the different types of risk and motives for risk management
»     Deal with risk management in forecasting and valuation
»    Understand recognition and measurement of banking in financial statements
»    Derive and interpret key performance metrics for banks
»    Apply valuation techniques to banking activities
»    Interpret financial statements on risk management and hedge accounting
»    Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular business analysis and valuation cases, and present and defend the joint findings at the end of the course

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The academic field of corporate finance examines the financial decisions made by business enterprises. An important part of corporate finance deals with the capital structure of the firm. Research on capital structure can provide tools to minimize the costs of obtaining financing for firms’ investments. The goal is to find the optimal mix of debt, equity and hybrid securities. Theories argue that firms choose between debt, equity, or hybrid securities to minimize costs that arise due to asymmetric information, agency problems, financial distress, and tax considerations. 

Another important financial decision for firms is whether to engage in mergers. Researchers have attempted to answer whether mergers add value, and in which circumstances. There could be very good reasons for firms to do a takeover. On the other hand, agency problems might be able to explain why firms sometimes engage in mergers that destroy value.

Agency problems occur because, even though shareholders are the owners of many corporations, it are the managers that make the day-to-day decisions. Managers could have different incentives than shareholders. For example, managers might have a tendency to overinvest in mergers as this could increase their status and salary. 

The difference in incentives between shareholders and managers highlights the importance of corporate governance. Corporate governance is the field in finance that deals with ways in which firms are governed and thus the extent to which investors can assure themselves that managers act in investors’ best interest. The interest in corporate governance has increased substantially after a number of accounting scandals in the 21st century, in which the financial results of firms were misrepresented. The goal of good corporate governance is to avoid (accounting) fraud and to increase firm value by assuring that managers only pursue value-creating investment opportunities. Setting an appropriate executive compensation package is an important part of corporate governance.

The first part of the course provides students with advanced knowledge in capital structure theories that build on taxes, financial distress, and agency costs (static tradeoff theory), information asymmetry (the pecking order theory), and market timing. The second part of the course describes the developments in mergers and in corporate governance. Several practice problems will be discussed and a business case will be worked on.




  Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: the theory and evidence on firms’ optimal capital structure.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: determinants of firms’ corporate governance structures.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: recent developments into academic research on capital structure and corporate governance.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: empirical evidence on illegal financial behaviour.
  • Students are able to: critically assess firms’ debt-equity ratios.
  • Students are able to: critically assess firms’ corporate governance structure.
  • Students are able to: analyze empirical studies in the field of corporate finance.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Writing a report on a business case (ABN Amro) in a group to facilitate (online) networking among students in times of a pandemic

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud This course follows a problem-solving approach that synthesizes ideas from game theory, real options, and strategy for corporate decision-making. Corporate finance and corporate strategy have long been seen as different sides of the same coin. Though both focus on the same broad problem, investment decision-making, the gap between the two sides -- and between theory and practice -- remains large. This course synthesizes cutting-edge developments in corporate finance and related fields -- in particular, real options and game theory -- to help bridge this gap. The course covers a wide range of valuation examples, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, joint research ventures, product introductions, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment. The course will be given in close cooperation with people and organizations that are active in corporate finance, such as private equity investors, investment banks, and consultants. The course Corporate Finance and Strategy is structured in two modules. The first module introduces you to both traditional and new valuation principles for strategic investment. We review the basic concepts and foundations of the building blocks:
  • Traditional DCF-valuation (WACC- and APV-method)
  • Strategic management
  • The valuation of real options
  • Games and bidding strategy
This part provides an overview and develops step-by-step the various principles useful for valuation and analysis. Questions addressed include amongst others:
  • How can one determine the value of a project or a firm?
  • What is the value of a license that gives the firm an option to invest in commercial production of a new product?
  • How is the optimal investment policy influenced by competition? How does competition affect the premium being paid in M&A?
In the second module we discuss various applications and examples of private equity investment, acquisitions, and initial public offerings. Lectures by guest speakers will be an integral part of the course and provide an opportunity to become better acquainted with corporate finance in practice. This course provides the fundamentals for the seminar Advanced Corporate Finance and Private Equity. Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into fundamental economic theories in corporate finance (real options, game theory and behavioral theory).
  • Students have knowledge of different types of acquisitions and how they are structured and financed.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into strengths and weaknesses of using different types of valuation models, in the context where they can be applied.
  • Students are able to apply valuation models in a variety of contexts, such as firm valuation, private equity acquisition strategies, R&D investment in high-tech sectors, investments in infrastructure, and oil exploration investment.
  • Students are able to form an opinion based on different perspectives acquisitions and private equity investment.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar In the new structure we will illustrate applications, inspire, and motivate students, while the content is supported by digitization. We organized (sub) groups of smaller scale to support intensive forms of learning using case studies and assignments. We digitized this course with 3 types of webcasts for content and assignments.
1. For each week a 2D animation video provides an overview. In these animations we focus on the core of the course or of the lecture. Through the use of animations we simplify complex content and make it accessible to all students.
2. Advanced content videos provide in-depth content. These in-depth videos (varying between 5 and 10 minutes) can be used by students to prepare themselves for lectures and as a study preparation for the exam.
3. Assignment videos are useful as a preparation for question problems for the tutorials and as an exercise for the exam. Students can use these assignments to test their own knowledge and problem-solving skills. These assignment videos focus on difficult calculations.

college: Faculteit der Geneeskunde en Gezondheidswetenschappen (Erasmus MC)
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud At the centre of this course will be the recent advances in the development economics. The focus will be on the recent empirical literature. Students will need to read every week one research paper and have to hand in various assignments.

Topics discussed in class will include the role of human capital (health and education), access to financial services and the role of institutions in improving the lives of the poor.
Human capital is considered to be one of the most important determinants of economic growth and poverty reduction. Within the field of development economics several field experiments have been implemented to study how to improve access and demand of health care and attendance and performance of students in school. Also, the provision of financial services (credit, savings accounts, insurance) to poor people is a big challenge for the developing world. In the recent years, many countries experienced the "microfinance revolution", but access to formal savings accounts or insurance remains scarce. National and local institutions play an important role in shaping the economy and small changes can be crucial for improving the lives of many.
The final content and structure of the course will be discussed in the first session.
  Leerdoelen
  • To understand current issues in development economics with a focus on how access to credit, health care and education can be improved in developing countries (microfinance and human capital).
  • To study and present in groups at least one scientific article on a subject linked to the course.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar This year the course will be adapted to the new COVID19 guidelines and a lot of exchange between students and student and lecturer is expected to take place online. Extra Note that there are possibly student presentations starting from week 2. In that case students will have to form groups and commit to a presentation topic in week 1!

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The goal of this course is to learn how to analyze multivariate data. The course covers multivariate regression models (SUR), simultaneous equation models (identification and estimation), vector autoregressive models (cointegration) and parametric duration models (hazard models). Leerdoelen
  • To learn how to do inference in multivariate regression and time series models.
  • To be able to describe multivariate variables using multivariate econometric models and to do statistical inference in these models.
  • To be able to work with multivariate regression models (SUR), simultaneous equation models (3SLS, GMM), vector autoregressive models (cointegration) and parametric duration models (hazard models).

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. D. Fok (EUR), Dr C.S. Bos (VU)
 
Short subject description:
Advanced Econometrics I covers the background Econometric Theory and a set of Micro-econometric models.
 
Course contents:
The course is built up around the book of Cameron & Trivedi, with references to the material of Hansen. The first four lectures discuss ordinary least squares and related methods, maximum likelihood, hypothesis and specification testing. They are followed by a discussion of the main micro-econometric models, including models for binary and multinomial outcomes, tobit and selection models, and finally models for duration data.
 
Theoretical exercises are discussed throughout this course. Concepts are illustrated by means of simulations and empirical applications. In class, the Python programming environment is used, though students are free to choose their own.
Leerdoelen By the end of this course, students will have gained a thorough understanding of the theory behind basic least squares estimation and inference, and the extension towards estimation through a likelihood function. They are able to apply this knowledge on micro-econometric models, and understand the consequences of modelling decisions. This will set the scene for the more general models and estimators to be covered in Advanced Econometrics II and III.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
Instructors: Prof. F. Kleibergen (UvA) and Dr A. Pick (EUR)
 
Short subject description:
Advanced Econometrics II develops the necessary theory for understanding core econometric techniques based on regression, GMM and likelihood methods.
 
Course contents:
The course covers Program Evaluation, Clustering, Instrumental Variables, Generalized Method of Moments and Likelihood based techniques. Modeling approaches, estimation and testing methods are developed and asymptotic techniques and finite sample properties are discussed.
Leerdoelen Obtaining a deep understanding of econometric theory and the practice of producing econometric inference especially with respect to the specification, estimation, and testing of models for causal inference and for linear and nonlinear relationships by least-squares, instrumental variables and GMM or likelihood based techniques.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Instructors: Prof. H.P. Boswijk (UvA) and Prof. S.J. Koopman (VU)
 
Short subject description:
This course discusses advanced models and methods for the econometric analysis of economic and financial time series.
 
Course contents:
Several major advances in time-series econometrics and likelihood-based inference have occurred in the past years. These advances have provided a major breakthrough in the modeling of time series using advanced up-to-date econometric methodologies. The first part of the course aims to provide a thorough understanding of linear time series models, including frequency domain analysis, multivariate models and cointegration. The second part focusses on state space models and the Kalman filter, discussing signal extraction, maximum likelihood estimation and dynamic factor models. The course will also discuss ARCH and score-driven volatility models. Various empirical illustrations in economics and finance will be discussed.
 
  Leerdoelen Students will receive a good training in time-series econometrics, the modeling of economic and financial time series using advanced techniques.

course_title: Advanced Economic Aspects of Cultural Industries
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['AC Crotta', 'dr. ASV Radermecker', 'dr. C Dalla Chiesa']
text:
Inhoud The course begins with the illustration of the definition of the cultural industries, then it focuses on a general analysis of the economics of the firm and of markets (industrial organization) and of the institutional and policy framework in which the cultural industries operate. The course builds up to an economic analysis of technological change in the cultural industries and the implications for all types of stakeholders.
To ensure that all participants have a fair chance of performing well, all students must have passed an elementary course in the principles of microeconomics.
  Leerdoelen The aim of this course is to develop students' understanding of the economics of the cultural industries. The course encourages students to apply economic analysis to an industry of their choice. Like any course in applied economics, this course stimulates students to use theory for developing logically consistent explanations of developments in the cultural industries and for making well-founded predictions. Successful students will also learn to appreciate the limitations of theory, explanation and predictions.

course_title: Advanced Economics of Arts and Culture
college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud ‘Advanced economics of arts and culture’ consists of lectures in cultural economics that articulate the application of the economic framework to the arts, culture, heritage and creative industries. The course relates economic principles and analyses to sectors such as the performing arts, visual arts, and the museum and heritage sectors, in which it investigates the role and activities of the main stakeholders: political decision-makers, policymakers, consumers, producers, patrons, etc. Topics under scope include: the rationale and instruments for public support; demand and supply of cultural goods; prices; the functioning of the art market; artists’ labour markets; the economics of cultural heritage; impact.

Note: This course is only open to BA students in Cultural Studies and exchange students with some basic knowledge of economics (e.g. high school level of economics). The lectures of this course are mandatory.
  Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to develop students' understanding of economics as it applies to the world of the arts and culture. Cultural economics studies economic decision-making by artists, organizations, policy-makers and consumers in the cultural sector. After the course, students will be able to evaluate the economic aspects of cultural policy and the market for cultural goods and services, based on economic theories about the arts, culture and creativity.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['prof.dr. MG Faure, LL.M', 'prof.dr. NJ Philipsen', 'prof.dr. RJ Van den Bergh']
text:
Inhoud This course is designed to provide students with advanced skills on the enforcement of law in the field of regulation of markets. In particular, students learn how to use economic arguments and economic evidence in real-life cases in courts and/or regulatory agencies. The course is organized in a moot court format. Students must take the role of plaintiffs, defendants, regulators or regulatees. They are supposed to base their arguments and decisions, both orally and in writing, on economic analysis of law. The topics, which are reviewed yearly, include inter alia competition law, product liability, mergers and acquisitions, financial and consumer law.
This course is open for EMLE students only.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud This course provides a thorough understanding of key results from the academic literature on optimal taxation. The course is largely normative in its scope, and addresses the following questions and more: What are the distortive costs of taxation? Should commodity taxes be differentiated? How should marginal income taxes vary with income? What is the optimal tax rate for top incomes? Should capital income be taxed? And if so, why? What is the role of taxation in a risky economic environment? What is the role of corporate income taxation? If the government can redistribute income with progressive taxes, is there still a role for other instruments such as the minimum wage? The course consists of two weekly Lectures that deal with the above questions in detail. Every Lecture has a dual goal: to provide students with a thorough understanding of theoretical underpinnings, and to discuss the practical implications, of the academic field of optimal taxation. At the end of the period, students’ understanding of the material will be tested by means of a final closed-book exam. Leerdoelen
  • To gain knowledge on the principals of optimal taxation.
  • To understand how taxes affect market outcomes, efficiency, the distribution of resources, and social welfare.
  • To understand how taxes can optimally strike a balance between equity and efficiency.
  • To apply the insights from optimal taxation to actual policy debates.
  • To provide a reasoned, critical assessment of much of the tax system in the Netherlands (or any other country).
  • To be able to derive and interpret simple rules for optimal policy.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Some topics may vary but the course remains largely the same.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The objective of this course is to develop students’ knowledge and understanding of important financial accounting topics, including goodwill, investment, current and non-current liability, pensions, and leases. This course continues where the Bachelor-2 course (Intermediate Accounting, FEB12007/FEB12007X) left off.

  Leerdoelen Develop students' knowledge and understanding of important financial accounting topics
Develop students' knowledge to understand financial accounting issues in practice
  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The exam will be 100% open questions to better assess students' achievement.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Course content, description
It is a data-driven world with an extreme competition for analytical talent, according to research by McKinsey Global Institute and McKinsey Analytics in 2017. In this course, I will discuss two main techniques to deal with structured data and unstructured data at entry level: 1) textual analysis and 2) machine learning. It aims to introduce a set of analytical tools for understanding and examining real-time data examples in R. Students need to complete empirical assignments in R to enhance the knowledge and skills learned in the course.
  Leerdoelen Learning objectives
After having followed this course, students should:

»      Understand structured and unstructured data;
»      Apply textual analysis to work with R on unstructured data;
»      Apply machine learning techniques to work with R on structured data;
»      Analyze real-life cases with analytic thinking.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud Contents, course description

In this course we will learn some general principles about financial modeling in Excel. We will read through a selection of classical finance studies and will try to replicate these studies in Excel. The topics we will cover range from asset pricing and performance evaluation to bond markets and private equities. Leerdoelen Learning Objectives
​
After having followed this course students are able to build Excel models using best-practice modelling techniques, and using a wide range of Excel functionalities required for financial calculations and for presenting results, knowing which technique is appropriate for which purpose and knowing how apply each technique correctly.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
  • Earnings quality and cash flows versus accruals
  • Creating condensed financial statements
  • Forecasting of future firm performance
  • Equity Valuation (Residual Income Valuation)
  • Financial analysis
Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: accounting quality, earnings management practices, and management incentives.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: accruals versus cash flows.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: condensed financial statements.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: ratio analysis.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: prospective analysis.
  • Students are able to: analyze the contents of financial statements of real-world companies.
  • Students are able to: scrutinize the contents of financial statements of real-world companies.
  • Students are able to: make forecasts of a company’s future financial performance based on current financial statements.
  • Students are able to: assess the value of a company based on current financial statements and projections of future financial performance.
  • Assignment: Critically assess and report on the quality of the financial statements, the financial prospects, and the value of a designated company.

course_title: Advanced Game Theory: Applications of Bargaining and Network Theory
college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'H Mokri', 'H Penton', 'I Corro Ramos, PhD', 'MS Holleman']
text:
Inhoud Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, such as decision trees and Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis, model validation, finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.

This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a cost-effectiveness model for their thesis.

Course structure
During this course of 6 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a working group session where students can ask specific questions regarding that week’s assignment if they need so. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. Two of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The third feedback session will be based on model review of the faculty.

Exam
The exam is composed of four parts:
•    Framing document ( individual) 20%
•    1 submodel (group), 15%
•    Final model (group) 25%
•    Final report 40% (20% for introduction to results, group, and 20% conclusion and discussion, individual)

Only the final grade (100%) will be published in Osiris.

  Leerdoelen This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students.

By the end of the course the student is able to:
  • set up the framing of an economic evaluation.
  • construct, populate and analyse a cost-effectiveness model using a Markov model.
  • critically assess models for technical errors.
  • deliver a report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
  • discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['dr. A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'H Penton', 'I Corro Ramos, PhD', 'MS Holleman']
text:
Inhoud Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, based on the principles of health state transition modelling or Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. In this advanced course, we will discuss e.g. more advanced model structures, survival analysis,  finding cost and utility input for your model, and how to build a probabilistic sensitivity analysis into your model.

This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a cost-effectiveness model for their thesis.
 
Course structure
During this course of 5 weeks, each week will be spent on a specific topic. A lecture will introduce the main elements of that week. In some weeks there will be a working group session where students can ask specific questions regarding that week’s assignment if they need so. In one week a computer exercise will be done to help students learn how to estimate and extrapolate survival curves from published data.

Subsequently, the excel-based models that were built by the students will be used for feedback sessions, to further develop modelling principles and skills. One of these feedback sessions will be based on peer review, that is, each group will assess the models of two other groups, and report on them during the feedback session. The other feedback sessions will be based on model review of the faculty.


 
Requirements
  • It is important for students to have basic knowledge of statistics; students should be familiair with concepts such as the Normal distribution and confidence intervals.
  • Laptop with Excel spreadsheet-software.
Exam
  • Framing document setting out the boundaries of the decision problem (20% of final grade, individual work)
  • Excel spreadsheet on the basis of which cost-effectiveness analyses can be executed, including sensitivity analyses (2 intermediate models at 10% of final grade each plus a final model at 20% of the final grade, group work)
  • Final report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed, and results, ending with a thorough discussion, reflecting on strengths and weaknesses of study (40% of final grade, 20% individual for discussion section and 20% group work for introduction to results section).
  • Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.
Re-sit
If a student fails the course, the resit will consist of delivering a final model and a final report, each counting as 50% of the final grade. Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.
  Leerdoelen This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students.

By the end of the course the student is able to:
  • set up the framing of an economic  evaluation.
  • construct, populate and  analyse a cost-effectiveness model based on Markov modelling.
  • critically assess models for technical errors.
  • deliver a technical report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
  • discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The course focuses on understanding complex financial reporting issues such as business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, hedge accounting and financial instruments. Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into the IFRS topics: business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, joint ventures and financial instruments.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into the international dimension of financial accounting and the role of the IASB.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into the incentives management face in applying IFRS and why accounting regulation is important.
  • Students are able to prepare and understand the parts of the annual report that relate to business combinations, consolidation, foreign currencies, joint ventures and financial instruments.
  • Students are able to critically reflect on management incentives with respect to applying IFRS.
Extra Written (re-)examination with essay questions (100%)

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration.
The analysis of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of a regulator, households and firms. The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics.
The course focuses on current issues in the international economic order, mostly within a general equilibrium framework.


  Leerdoelen
  • The course focuses on the world economy as such and the relationships between countries and trading blocks regarding international goods trade, capital flows and worker migration.
  • The analysis of trade policy measures heavily draws on IO-theories to explain the behavior of a regulator, households and firms.
  • The course starts with a refresher in basic microeconomics topics. The course focuses on current issues in the international economic order, mostly within a general equilibrium framework.
  • The students should understand the microeconomics foundations of general equilibrium trade theories, as well as applying them in computer-based simulations of real world situations.
Extra Minimum average grade to pass this course: 5.5

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The following inventory control models will be covered in the course:
1. Single-location, single-item systems: standard (r,Q) and (s,S) policies with different demand distributions. Evaluation of service levels and costs. Optimization of policy parameters. Continuous and periodic review models. Deterministic and stochastic lead times.
2. Coordinated ordering: power-of-2 policies, joint replenishment model, production smoothing.
3. Multi-echelon systems: concepts and models, lot sizing, METRIC approach, guaranteed-service approach. Leerdoelen After completing this course, students will be able to understand, use, implement, and extend basic and advanced models and concepts of inventory control and supply chain management. Extra The final grade is determined as 0.8x + 0.2(y_1 + y_2) where x is your grade for the written exam (or resit exam) and y_i is your grade for Assignment i = 1, 2.
The written exam grade has to be greater than or equal to 5.0.
Assignments: By working on these homework assignments, you will be able to use and implement models you learnt during the lectures.
Working on these assignments is crucial for your success in this course.  
Written Exam: There is a closed-book, written exam at the end of the course.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
A major part of this course will touch upon the field of Asset Pricing, especially in the lectures regarding the modeling of risk. A proper understanding of risk is fundamental to many financial management applications such as capital budgeting, risk management, portfolio selection and performance evaluation. Subjects include:
  • Basics of Portfolio Theory & CAPM: Normative vs. positive, assumptions, testable implications, pricing errors/kernel.
  • Anomalies: Size, value, momentum & reversal anomalies, why use sorted portfolios.
  • Return and return distributions: Expected return, non-normality, incorporating skewness and kurtosis, the role of expectations and information.
  • Utility functions: First principles (nonsatiation, risk aversion, skewness preference), types of risk aversion, downside risk, Stochastic Dominance.
Leerdoelen
  • Students have knowledge of theory on diversification.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into asset pricing models and anomalies.
  • Students know how to construct optimal portfolios in mean-variance and non-mean-variance frameworks.
  • Students are able to test for the existence of asset pricing anomalies.
  • Students are able to conduct performance evaluation on investment portfolios.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changes will be implemented in the contents of the course; the format of the teaching and exam may be adjusted to allow for online delivery.
  Extra Students can also obtain a bonuspoint of maximum 0.5 on their final grade through their participation in the Advanced Investments debate.

For the debate, students will be randomly assigned into teams of 5 or 6 students. These teams will compete over two rounds. Details are available on Canvas. Conditions are as follows:
  • Everyone who participated in the debate, measured by a participation in round 2, in a team that debates or as part of the judging pool, will get a bonus of 0.3 on their exam grade. 
  • Everyone who is part of a team that presents good arguments in their debate (be it in round 1 or round 2) and qualifies for the 0.3 bonus, will see that bonus increased to 0.5. 
NB: those who make quality arguments in round 1 but drop out in round 2 will not receive any bonus at all. The reward for quality argument is an increase to 0.5, the bonus is capped at 0.5 in total. No retakes or make-up assignments for the bonuspoint will be allowed.

college: Erasmus School of Law
lecturers: ['dr. I Kampourakis', 'dr.mr. MCM Geuskens', 'mr.dr. C Elion - Valter']
text: Inhoud The course focuses on reading the 1990 book by Iris Marion Young, Justice and the Politics of Difference. While that text rejects as insufficient theories of justice that center on questions of (re)distribution and argues that justice importantly relates to the social standing and ordering of social groups, it is a place to start when understanding current day social movements that seek to oppose oppression and domination of members of marginalized groups, ending forms of injustice that. Leerdoelen In this course students are introduced to critical theories of justice and critical theoretical approaches to law. The aim of the course is that students can use such theories to analyze and explain the existence and aims of today’s social movements such as #MeToo and #BLM, and that they can use these theories to explain, analyze, evaluate and critique the possible ways in which law(s) and policies could be shaped to redress (structural) injustice. The course has as an important aim to advance students’ philosophical skills, by reading and discussing seminal works (mainly: Iris Marion Young, Justice and the Power of Difference, and Carol Smart’s The Power of Law), as well as writing argumentative essays of various lengths. This is why there are both written and oral assignments and why active class participation is not only required but also graded.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
  • Consumption and Saving
  • Business Cycles
Leerdoelen
  • To obtain knowledge on the macroeconomics of consumption and saving.
  • To obtain knowledge on modern macroeconomic business cycle analysis.
  • Understand modern macroeconomic models at an advanced level.
  • To read and understand macroeconomic research papers with respect to consumption, saving and business cycles.
  • To have an overview of the theoretical and empirical approaches of macroeconomics.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar The 5th edition of David Romer is now used as the recommended text.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud With respect to your previous classes in management accounting, this course offers a closer look into management accounting and control topics.
The Institute of Management Accountants (an U.S.-based institution) defines management accounting as "a value-adding continuous improvement process of planning, designing, measuring and operating nonfinancial and financial information systems that guides management action, motivates behavior, and supports and creates the cultural values necessary to achieve an organization's strategic, tactical and operating objectives." In accordance with the definition, we will examine various topics concerning management accounting and control discussed in literature and used by managers for decision management and decision control. Leerdoelen
  • To broaden and deepen the knowledge of students gained during prior courses in Management Accounting.
  • To understand (new) concepts, techniques and (external) forces influencing nowadays Management Accounting and Management Control. Interaction between practical cases and theoretical concepts is essential.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No significant changes, except the new book and the new cases for the tutorials.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud In each week a different modeling technique is discussed. Examples are models for sales, models for market shares, Hidden Markov Models, Conjoint analysis, modeling heterogeneity, and modeling dynamics. For all topics we will discuss the technical details of the techniques as well as how to apply the techniques and how to interpret the model results. Leerdoelen
  • In this course students learn how to specify, estimate, and use a number of popular advanced models in quantitative marketing research.
  • Students know and understand the state-of-the-art techniques in quantitative marketing.
  • Students know which quantitative marketing technique to apply in a concrete, applied setting.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar No major changed planned.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud Banks, insurers and pension funds feature daily in the financial press. The credit crisis has triggered a public debate on the risks, rewards and the costs of the banking, pension and insurance industry. Fundamental questions abound. Why do banks exist? Was it a good idea in 2008 to rescue Bear Stearns, the insurer AIG and let Lehman Brothers fail? What are the cost and benefits of bank supervision? Is there too much leverage in the system? Do financial conglomerates increase or lower the risks for the financial system? What about full reserve banking as an alternative for fractional reserve banking? How is the sector coping with the Corona crisis? What will be the effects of this new crisis in the longer run; will it turn into a financial crisis? We extensively discuss the role and risks of the financial industry and the connection with monetary policy.

This course addresses these kinds of questions by digging deeper. Due to asymmetric information it is difficult to match the supply of credit with the demand for credit. The financial services sector is the intermediary platform that helps to bridge the divide, albeit imperfectly. Due to the asymmetric information endemic to financial services, risk management is an integral part of the services. We discuss how financial institutions’ management, regulators and supervisors deal with the various risks they face. Risk management is analyzed on the level of an individual bank or insurer, and on the systems level. Bank runs can be devastating for the entire sector and the real economy. Regulation and supervision are thus an important aspect of the government interference with the financial sector. The interplay between monetary policy and banks is essential for the understanding the risks and behavior of the financial sector at a macro scale.
On the methodological side the course freely uses concepts from calculus such as elementary differentiation and integration rules and concepts from statistics such as distribution functions and densities, means, variances and the covariance. We also use concepts from micro economics, game theory (Nash equilibrium) and macro monetary economics.

The main topics of this course are:
  • The industrial organization view versus the asymmetric information paradigm
  • Moral hazard and adverse selection
  • Wholesale banking, relationship banking, asset based lending and adverse selection
  • Risk analysis, Value-at-Risk and heavy tails
  • Bank fragility: Bank runs, systemic risk & diversification, regulation and supervision
  • Systemic risk and the credit crises
  • Monetary policy, interest rate risk and credit risk
Leerdoelen
  • Students understand the asymmetric information paradigm as the main explantion for the existence of financial services and the problem that this causes.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: the risk management of a financial service provider and the systemic risk of the sector.
  • Students have knowledge of and insight into: the interplay between monetary and macroeconomc policy.
  • Students are able to: analyze the financial services industry using information economics and risk analysis. The students are able to analyze novel situations not treated in class, but using the class notes.
  • Students are able to: analyze the interaction between the financial sector and the monetary economy.
Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Several changes were made in the curriculum. This year the topic of the essay concerns the risk in the financial sector by means of a novel measure, the MES (marginal expected shortfall). To estimate this risk new lecture notes will be provided and a spread sheet is offered to help the student gauging this risk. A new lecture on Dutch monetarism is planned. As every year, we discuss and analyze the financial press in class. Extra Assignment (15%), Essay (20%), Exam (65%)

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The course starts by introducing the fundamental data structures (e.g., arrays and lists) and complexity analysis for algorithms (using Big-Oh notation). After that, advanced data structures (e.g., stacks and queues) are discussed, followed by tree representations (e.g., search trees) and algorithms that allow to traverse them.

Students will have the opportunity to practice with the taught material by doing several assignments. All the course examples and exercises will be given for the Java programming language. Leerdoelen
  • Understand basic data structures (e.g., arrays, lists, etc.) and complexity analysis of algorithms.
  • Understand advanced data structures (e.g., stacks, queues, etc.) and tree representations and their associated algorithms.
  • Be able to build data structures and algorithms in the Java programming language.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud The course starts by studying the concept of recursion and its relation to iteration. Then problems will be analyzed that are much easier to solve by recursion than iteration. After that we study several searching and sorting algorithms, and how to estimate and compare the performance of these algorithms. Several applications of these techniques will also be investigated.
 
Students will do individual assignments on the previously mentioned topics. Leerdoelen
  • For computer architecture: knowledge and understanding of the building blocks of a computer, the main components of a computer network, and the principles according to which modern computers are designed.
  • For programming: knowledge and understanding of the basic concepts of programming and how to write programs in the Java programming language for solving elementary problems.
  • For databases: knowledge and understanding of the entity-relationship diagram (ERD), what is a relational database, how to query a relational database using the Structured Query Language (SQL), and how to design a relational database.
  • For business intelligence knowledge and understanding of the basic concepts in business intelligence and a selection of data mining techniques used for business intelligence.
  • Be able to perform hardware comparisons.
  • Be able to develop Java programs.
  • Be able to design and query relational databases.
  • Be able to apply data mining techniques for business intelligence.

college: Erasmus School of Economics
text:
Inhoud
This course is concerned with normative public economics. A choice is made each year from the following topics:
  • The first and second welfare theorems
  • The theory of second-best and dead-weight loss
  • Optimal non-linear income tax
  • Optimal participation taxes
  • Optimal indirect taxes
  • Optimal capital income taxes
  • Optimal participation taxes
  • Optimal taxes/subsidies on human capital and provision of education
  • Optimal provision of public goods and social cost-benefit analysis
  • Optimal corrective (environmental) taxes/regulation
  • Optimal minimum wage policies
The course links the optimal tax principles to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top rate of the income tax, taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.
 
Leerdoelen
  • To gain knowlegde of the principles of public finance.
  • To learn to apply principles of public finance to policy questions like:
    • How progressive should the income tax be?
      Should the government employ indirect taxes besides the income tax?
      How should the government set the optimal capital tax?
      Should the government subsidize education?
      How does taxation affect human capital investment and how does this affect the progression of the income tax?
      How should the government internalize externalities, for example in the environment?
      How much public goods should the government provide?
      What is the marginal cost of public funds and how should second-best policy rules correct for tax distortions?
  • To be able to understand:
    • the concepts of welfare economics 
    • the optimal non-linear income tax
    • the optimal commodity tax and the debate on direct vs. indirect taxation
    • the optimal tax on capital income 
    • the optimal taxation of human capital
    • the optimal corrective tax on externalities
    • the Samuelson rule for public goods provision
    • the marginal cost of public funds.
  • To be able to derive and interpret simple optimal rules for optimal policies in second-best.
    To be able to apply many concepts from microeconomics and mathematics such as:
    • differentiation of functions:
    • partial and total differentiation
    • the envelope theorem and the implicit function theorem,
    • maximization of functions with more than one variable
    • using the Lagrangian method of constrained optimization
    • models of consumer choice (consumption of various goods, the neoclassical labor supply model, and intertemporal choice.
  • To be able to link principles of public finance to actual policy discussions, for example, the flat-tax debate, the optimal progressivity of the income tax, the top-rate of the income tax, the taxation of capital incomes, greening the tax system, discussions on the optimal size of the public sector, the role of the government in (higher) education, etc.
  • To be able to conduct simple simulations of optimal public policies on the computer.



  Wijziging t.o.v. voorgaand jaar Lower study load

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
lecturers: ['C Modugno, MSc', 'dr. AFM Krijnen', 'dr. I Awad Cherit']
text:
Inhoud This course thoroughly familiarizes students with the theoretical background of qualitative research and its main approaches, including discourse and semiotic analysis, in-depth interviews, focus groups and ethnographic fieldwork, and less traditional methods such as photovoice. It discusses the research process as organic and addresses advantages and disadvantages of the dynamic (and often unpredictable) nature of qualitative research. These discussions are grounded in in-class exercises and close-reading of published research, paying special attention to the flexibility of the analytical frame and the relation between theory and empirical data.
  Leerdoelen Students have knowledge and understanding of:
  • The theoretical background of qualitative research
  • Qualitative research methods commonly used in social sciences
  • Critically evaluate the application of these methods
     
Students have developed skills to:
  • Formulate a relevant, qualitative research question within an appropriate research design
  • Apply commonly used qualitative methods in a sound and creative way
  • Report on their research design, application of methods and results of analysis (both orally and written)

college: Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences
text:
Inhoud Advanced Quantitative Methods is het vervolg op Quantitative Methods (Kwantitatieve Methoden). In Quantitative Methods heb je kennis genomen van de rol van statistiek in wetenschappelijk onderzoek en technieken leren gebruiken om onderzoeksgegevens te beschrijven. Bovendien heb je t-toets, Chi-kwadraat toets, correlatie en bivariate regressie leren kennen. Advanced Quantitative Methods begint met een herhaling van bivariate en multivariate regressieanalyse en bouwt daarmee voort op de eerder verworven kennis. De technieken die behandeld worden zijn betrouwbaarheidsanalyse, factoranalyse, multivariate regressieanalyse en logistische regressieanalyse. Bovendien ligt er grote nadruk op hoe conceptuele modellen naar statistische analyses kunnen worden vertaald (controle, moderatie, mediatie) en de elaboratie van relaties tussen concepten (replicatie, uitleg, interpretatie, specificatie).
De kennis en vaardigheden vergaard in het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods zijn voor een overgroot gedeelte nodig om kwantitatieve analyses uit te voeren en daarmee je onderzoeksvragen te beantwoorden. Zowel in de colleges als ook in de computerpractica wordt bij het vak Advanced Quantitative Methods daarom nadruk gelegd op de rapportage en interpretatie van onderzoeksresultaten.
Het onderwijs wordt gegeven aan de hand van webcolleges, hoorcolleges en SPSS-practica. Thuis en in wekelijkse practica wordt in afgebakende opdrachten geoefend met de behandelde stof. In de webcolleges en hoorcolleges komen de verschillende technieken aan bod maar wordt ook het verband gelegd met de praktische toepassing ervan die in de SPSS-practica plaats vindt.

  Leerdoelen Na afloop van dit vak ben je in staat om:
  • met behulp van betrouwbaarheidsanalyse en factoranalyse te beoordelen in hoeverre latente begrippen adequaat geoperationaliseerd zijn;
  • multiple regressieanalyse toe te passen op concrete (eventueel zelfbedachte) onderzoeksvragen;
  • te benoemen welke assumpties ten grondslag liggen aan multiple regressieanalyse;
  • conceptuele modellen op te stellen;
  • het onderscheid te maken tussen mediërende, modererende, onderdrukkende en spurieuze relaties;
  • moderatie tussen een discrete en een continue of twee continue variabelen te rapporteren en interpreteren;
  • moderatie tussen een discrete en een continue variabele in een grafiek weer te geven;
  • mediatie tussen een discrete en een continue of twee continue variabelen te rapporteren en interpreteren;
  • odds, odds ratio en kansen te berekenen;
  • logistische regressieanalyse te rapporteren en interpreteren.
 
Je bent verder in staat om de volgende analyses in SPSS uit te voeren:
  • factoranalyse;
  • betrouwbaarheidsanalyse;
  • multiple regressie, inclusief moderatie en mediatie;
  • variabelen te standaardiseren;
  • logistische regressieanalyse.

college: Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication
text:
Inhoud This course provides an overview and understanding of the more commonly used and applied multivariate, statistical techniques and the skills to design, carry out and judge sophisticated, quantitative research projects. Specifically, the course covers statistical techniques needed for data reduction (scale and factor analysis), cross-sectional analyses (multiple linear and logistic regression analysis, path analysis) and for comparative analysis (time-series analysis, multilevel and meta-analysis). The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or mathematics. The focus is on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques. Leerdoelen Students have advanced knowledge and understanding of:
  • Key concepts and assumptions in the more commonly used quantitative methods, in particular multivariate statistical methods for complex data.
  • How these statistical methods work and how their results should be interpreted.
Students have developed the skills to:
  • Formulate relevant research questions and answer these using appropriate statistical techniques (in particular multivariate statistical methods for complex data).
  • Use these statistical methods in a sound and creative way, More specifically, they are able to clean and transform data, check for assumptions, conduct analyses, and interpret the output.   
  • Report on their research design, operationalization, execution of the data analysis, and outcomes of the data analysis and their implications in the light of a relevant research question.

college: Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University
text:
Inhoud
  • Functions
  • Functional programming
  • Conditions
  • Vectors and data structures
  • Loops and some basic algorithms
  • Debugging and error trapping
  • Selected other topics
The course will be taught in English and is limited to 25 participants. Students are required to bring their own laptops to class (R and RStudio can be installed for free). The introductory R course is a prerequisite for this course. Exemptions from this requirement can be requested from the course's contact person. Leerdoelen

The open-source software environment R (www.R-project.org) is a powerful platform for data analysis and statistical graphics that has become the global standard in statistical computing. R houses an ever-growing extensive collection of tools for statistics and data analysis – an attractive basis for thorough exploration of your data. Furthermore, it provides a powerful programming language coupled with flexible graphical capabilities.
This follow-up to the introductory course will focus on programming in R. Basic programming concepts will be covered, such as accessing and altering parts of objects, controlling the order of computations, iteratively performing tasks using loops, and writing functions. We will also take a look at functional programming, and how to use these tools in practice. 
Upon completion of the course, you will be able to use the power of R’s programming language for advanced analytic tasks to improve the quality of your research.

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['DC Voormolen, MSc', 'dr. AMV Stoopendaal', 'dr. LE Oldenhof', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. RL Rolim Medeiros de Gruijl', 'dr. S Sülz', 'dr. SPI Huls', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'DV Ivanova, PhD']
text:
Inhoud Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for students who do not have such a background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture. A central element of the course is practically assessing the design and execution of existing successful and flawed studies.

Online workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where concepts and methods are put into practice after they have been introduced in online lectures and literature. Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.
 
The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on researching language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography), and on formulating theoretically informed research questions. In the final week, quantitative and qualitative methods will be combined and students will present their full assessments of several published studies.

Language: Only the workgroups are in Dutch
Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
 
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able
  • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory

  • to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
  • to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
  • to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
  • to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
  • to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences for design and interpretation in specific situations 
  • to recognize different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis) and develop a basic form of these analyses

  • to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research designs by using the distinction between gap spotting and problematization, and between inductive and deductive reasoning
  • to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using the observation dimensions
  • to evaluate digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms
  • to perform a basic ethnographic analysis by analysing empirical data, such as online communication

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['DC Voormolen, MSc', 'dr. AMV Stoopendaal', 'dr. HJ van Elten', 'dr. J Weenink', 'dr. JJ Schuurmans', 'dr. LE Oldenhof', 'dr. LMA Goossens', 'dr. ME van Bochove', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. RL Rolim Medeiros de Gruijl', 'dr. S Sülz', 'dr. SPI Huls', 'dr. VT Reckers - Droog', 'DV Ivanova, PhD', 'IWH van de Voort', 'J van Roekel, MSc', 'M Felder, MSc', 'MJC Aspria, MSc']

The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on researching language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography), and on formulating theoretically informed research questions. In the final week, quantitative and qualitative methods will be combined and students will present their full assessments of several published studies.
Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
 
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able
  • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory

  • to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
  • to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
  • to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
  • to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
  • to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences for design and interpretation in specific situations 
  • to recognize different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis) and develop a basic form of these analyses

  • to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research designs by using the distinction between gap spotting and problematization, and between inductive and deductive reasoning
  • to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using the observation dimensions
  • to evaluate digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms
  • to perform a basic ethnographic analysis by analysing empirical data, such as online communication

college: Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management
lecturers: ['DC Voormolen, MSc', 'dr. AMV Stoopendaal', 'dr. HJ van Elten', 'dr. J Weenink', 'dr. JJ Schuurmans', 'dr. LE Oldenhof', 'dr. LMA Goossens', 'dr. ME van Bochove', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. text:
Inhoud Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the internet deficiency modules that are offered by ESHPM. The deficiency modules might serve as a useful refresher to methodology for students who do not have such a background.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods. The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture. A central element of the course is practically assessing the design and execution of existing successful and flawed studies.

Online workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where concepts and methods are put into practice after they have been introduced in online lectures and literature. Students prepare cases before each session and discuss them with fellow students and with teachers during the meetings. The work in these sessions leads up to the exam.
 
The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding and interpreting qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on researching language (discourse analysis) and practices (ethnography), and on formulating theoretically informed research questions. In the final week, quantitative and qualitative methods will be combined and students will present their full assessments of several published studies.
 
Leerdoelen The aim of the course is to enhance students’ ability to interpret and critically assess scientific research. The emphasis is on quantitative causal inference, and on discourse analysis and ethnography. These skills can later be applied in subsequent courses and during the writing of the master thesis.
 
In order to achieve this aim, at the end of the course, students should be able
  • to apply criteria that are deemed valid in the respective research paradigms in the critical appraisal of published research articles (quantitative/qualitative), including the appropriate role for theory

  • to use causal theory in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
  • to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
  • to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
  • to apply a well-developed and critical understanding of the concepts of statistical uncertainty, statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
  • to distinguish between the three types of quantitative studies (causal inference, prediction and description) and recognize the consequences for design and interpretation in specific situations 
  • to recognize different forms of discourse analysis (critical discourse analysis, conversation analysis) and develop a basic form of these analyses

  • to evaluate the role of theory in qualitative research designs by using the distinction between gap spotting and problematization, and between inductive and deductive reasoning
  • to judge the quality of observations in ethnography by using the observation dimensions
  • to evaluate digital and multi-sited ethnographic studies in ethical and methodological terms
  • to perform a basic ethnographic analysis by analysing empirical data, such as online communication
